name: Information Security & Privacy Governance
description: Assigns clear ownership and management accountability for security and privacy, keeps policies current, and measures compliance through regular reviews.

content.text: – Define clear ownership for security and privacy and ensure decisions are documented.
– All personnel, contractors, information systems, SaaS/IaaS services and company-managed devices.
Record names in the Comp AI platform.
Re-confirm role assignments at least annually and after role changes.
SPO presents a concise security status during a scheduled management on an as needed basis.
Senior management signs an annual statement acknowledging ultimate responsibility for security and privacy.
Allocate at least one measurable security improvement task per sprint or work cycle.
Store all policies in Comp AI; SPO verifies access and link integrity annually.
Maintain version control with change logs.
Merge or retire overlapping policies to keep each document brief.
New personnel read this policy set and electronically acknowledge before receiving system access.
Distribute security awareness training on an annual basis and record completion.
– Annual check that: policies exist, SPO is documented, annual sign-off filed, awareness log current.
– Document deviations in a “Security-Decisions” log with reason and expiry.
– Missing logs or overdue actions corrected within two weeks or escalated at the next management review.
– Audit and incident lessons feed into the next scheduled policy refresh.

name: Compliance & Regulatory Monitoring
description: atalogues all legal, regulatory, and contractual obligations, links them to controls and evidence, and tracks enquiries and gaps to closure.

content.text: – Identify applicable laws, standards and contractual commitments and keep proof of conformance.
– All products, data processing activities, jurisdictions of operation and contractual obligations.
Maintain a plain-language list of relevant legal and industry requirements.
Review the list semi-annually or upon market expansion.
For every applicable requirement record: Internal Control Reference and Evidence Link.
Refresh evidence at least annually; schedule reminders before links expire.
Flag any missing evidence as a
Use a dedicated email alias forwarding to compliance contacts.
Acknowledge external compliance enquiries within 48 hours.
Log date, question and resolution reference in the Compliance Register.
Conduct a 30-minute annual sweep to update links and close gaps.
Record the review date in the register header.
– No evidence older than 12 months; zero gaps open beyond 30 days.
– Deferred items require documented justification and target date approved by senior management.
– Unanswered enquiries or overdue gaps escalated to the next management meeting and added to the work backlog.
– After each audit or major customer questionnaire, adjust evidence format to streamline future requests.

name: Remote Access & BYOD
description: Approves secure VPN or zero-trust methods, sets endpoint hardening and mobile controls, and logs and reviews remote sessions.

content.text: – Secure connectivity for off-site work while protecting company data on personal and remote devices.
– All remote network connections and any personally owned devices used for company activities.
Use VPN or zero-trust proxy with MFA for administrative or data-sensitive access.
SSH only with key-based auth; prohibit direct RDP/SSH from the public internet.
Disable remote access on systems where not required.
Devices must run supported OS, be fully patched, and have disk encryption enabled.
Install company-approved endpoint protection and auto-lock after 15 minutes idle.
Register BYOD devices; enforce PIN/biometric, encryption, and remote-wipe capability.
Company email and data stored in managed app or container where feasible.
Remove company data and access immediately upon contract end or device loss.
Log VPN and privileged remote sessions; retain logs for at least 90 days.
Auto-disconnect inactive VPN sessions after 12 hours or shorter if supported.
Review remote-access logs monthly for anomalies.
– Quarterly sample confirms 100 % of remote devices meet patch/encryption policy; VPN logs reviewed.
– Temporary allowance for unsupported device requires management approval and remediation timeline.
– Non-compliant device blocked from network until remediated; repeat violations escalated to HR/management.
– Evaluate new secure-access technologies and refine BYOD requirements annually.

name: Physical Security & Environmental
description: Controls facility and server-room access, manages visitors, safeguards against fire, flood, or climate risks, and audits logs and walk-throughs.

content.text: – Protect personnel, equipment, and information from unauthorised physical access or environmental damage.
– Offices, co-working spaces, data-centre cages, and any site hosting company assets.
Use electronic badge or key system; disable badges immediately upon employment termination.
Segregate secure areas (e.g., server closets) with locked doors; limit keys to authorised staff.
Require sign-in, government-issued ID, and visible visitor badge.
Host must escort visitor at all times; log retained 12 months.
Equip server areas with smoke detection and automatic fire suppression or fire-rated cabinets.
Elevate equipment or use leak sensors in flood-prone areas.
Cable-lock laptops in shared spaces; lock server racks.
Sanitize or destroy storage media prior to disposal or reuse; record disposal event.
CCTV or access-control logs reviewed monthly for anomalies.
Conduct annual walk-through to verify controls and signage.
– Access logs show 100 % badge use; visitor log complete; yearly inspection report filed.
– Temporary unsecured space usage requires compensating controls (e.g., lockable cabinet).
– Tailgating or propped-open doors reported as incidents; corrective action within one week.
– Enhance controls based on incident trends and facility changes.

name: Vendor & Third-Party Risk
description: Inventories vendors, tiers them by data impact, conducts due diligence, embeds security clauses in contracts, and monitors attestations and incidents.

content.text: – Manage risks from suppliers that access company data or impact operations.
– All SaaS, cloud, consulting, and data-processing vendors.
Maintain central list of active vendors with owner and contact.
Tier vendors by risk (High = handles customer or Restricted data; Medium = internal tools; Low = no data access).
High-risk: obtain SOC 2/ISO 27001 report or complete security questionnaire before contract.
Medium-risk: basic questionnaire or public security statement review.
Include confidentiality, breach-notification, right-to-audit, and data-return clauses.
For personal-data processors, execute a data-processing agreement.
Review High-risk vendors’ attestations or questionnaires annually.
Track security-breach news; initiate assessment if incident reported.
On contract end, ensure vendor deletes or returns data; obtain written confirmation.
Remove integrations and access tokens within 48 h.
– 100 % High-risk vendors have up-to-date due-diligence evidence; inventory reconciled quarterly.
– Urgent onboarding without full diligence allowed only with executive sign-off and action plan.
– Missing evidence or expired contracts flagged to procurement and Security for immediate action.
– Streamline questionnaire, add automation, and refine tiering criteria annually.

name: Risk Management
description: Maintains a living risk register, scores and prioritises threats, sets treatment actions, and injects threat-intel updates into decision-making.

content.text: – Identify, rank and address material risks in a repeatable, lightweight manner.
– Strategic, operational, technical, vendor, legal and financial risks affecting the organization.
on Comp AI platform that contains: Risk, Impact, Likelihood, Owner, Treatment.
Add or update entries when launching new services, adopting vendors, or learning of relevant threat events.
Ensure the register is never blank.
Use simple 1-5 scoring for Impact and Likelihood.
Highlight the three highest-scoring risks each quarter.
Record rationale for any score change.
Choose a response for highlighted risks:
Create one actionable task with a due date for each decision other than Accept.
Mark “Accepted” items with date and approving manager initials.
Subscribe to reputable free alerts (e.g., national CERT, CISA, major cloud vendor advisories).
Post relevant items to an internal threat-intel channel and add new risks or actions when applicable.
– Register exists, three risks flagged, and no mitigation task more than 30 days overdue.
– Acceptance of any High-impact risk requires documented senior-management approval.
– Register empty or stale (>90 days) triggers discussion at the next management meeting until resolved.
– Closed or obsolete risks are removed during quarterly review to keep the list concise.

name: Data Classification & Handling
description: Uses a four-tier classification scheme to label data and prescribes access, encryption, sharing, and disposal rules for each level.

content.text: – Protect information proportionately by assigning sensitivity levels and prescribing handling requirements.
– All data created, received, processed, or stored by the organisation, regardless of medium or location.
Adopt four levels: Public, Internal, Confidential, Restricted.
Define examples and default level (Internal) in a quick-reference guide.
Label documents and data stores at creation using headers, metadata tags, or folder names.
Automated tools may tag files where supported; otherwise manual labels are required for Confidential and Restricted data.
Grant access on least-privilege basis aligned to classification level.
Encrypt Confidential and Restricted data at rest and in backups.
Log administrative access to Restricted data.
Use encrypted channels (e.g., TLS, SFTP) for Confidential or Restricted data.
Prohibit public-cloud file links without access control when data is above Internal.
External sharing of Restricted data requires management approval and NDA or contract.
Apply retention periods from the Data Retention Policy to each classification.
Destroy media holding Confidential or Restricted data using secure wipe or certified shredding.
– Quarterly sample confirms correct labels, encryption, and access rights; ≥ 95 % accuracy target.
– Must document risk and compensating controls; senior management approval required.
– Mislabelled or mishandled data triggers incident response and mandatory refresher training.
– Update examples and tooling as new data types or regulations emerge.

name: Secure Configuration & Hardening
description: Publishes baseline hardening guides, uses version-controlled IaC, detects configuration drift, and backs up critical configs.

content.text: – Ensure all systems start and stay in a hardened, defensible state.
– Cloud resources, containers, virtual machines, network devices, laptops, and mobile devices.
Publish industry-aligned baselines for each OS / platform.
Include firewall rules, disabled services, logging, and banner settings.
Store config files/IaC in version control; require pull-request review.
Annotate commit messages with ticket or change-request ID.
Run weekly scans comparing live configs to baselines.
Remediate or approve justified drift within five business days.
Snapshot critical configs (firewalls, IaC state) after approved changes.
Retain last five versions; encrypt backups and test restore quarterly.
– ≥ 95 % assets pass weekly drift scan; baselines reviewed annually.
– Document risk and compensating controls; review quarterly.
– Unauthorised config change triggers incident response and rollback.
– Update baselines after incidents or new threat intel.

name: Acceptable Use & Workstation Security
description: Sets responsible use rules, enforces endpoint encryption, patching, auto-lock, and restricts personal storage of company data.

content.text: – Define responsible use of company systems and secure configuration of endpoints.
– All users and devices accessing company networks or data.
Use company assets for authorised business activities; limited personal use allowed if it doesn’t create risk.
Prohibit illegal, harassing, or copyright-infringing activities.
Enable full-disk encryption, host firewall, and automatic OS patches.
Auto-lock after 10 minutes idle and require password/PIN to resume.
Users must not forward company data to personal email.
Use approved messaging tools for business discussions.
Collect printed sensitive docs immediately; shred when done.
BYOD must meet endpoint-security requirements (PIN, encryption, patching) and register with IT.
Store company data only in approved, encrypted containers or apps.
– Quarterly workstation audit checks encryption, lock settings, and patch status.
– Temporary deviation (e.g., lab testing) requires documented approval and time limit.
– Policy breaches result in access suspension until remediation; severe cases escalate to HR.
– Update rules with new collaboration tools and emerging endpoint threats.

name: Background Screening & On/Off-boarding
description: Screens new hires, provisions least-privilege access, disables accounts and recovers assets at exit, and archives records securely.

content.text: – Verify workforce integrity, grant the right access at start, and promptly revoke it at end of engagement.
– All employees, contractors, interns, and temporary staff.
Conduct identity verification and right-to-work checks for all hires.
Perform criminal or reference checks proportional to role sensitivity.
Complete screening before system access is granted; document outcomes.
Manager submits access request ticket listing required systems and role.
Provide security training and policy acknowledgement within first week.
HR/manager notifies IT of termination date at least 24 h in advance.
Disable accounts and collect badges by close of last working day.
Schedule exit interview to remind departing staff of confidentiality obligations.
Recover all company-owned devices; verify data wipe before reuse.
Compare recovered asset list against inventory; investigate discrepancies.
Remove access from third-party tools (e.g., Slack, Git, cloud) within 24 h.
Store screening results and off-boarding checklist in secure HR system for seven years or legal minimum.
– Monthly audit confirms 100 % terminated accounts disabled and assets returned.
– Any skipped screening step requires executive approval and risk note in personnel file.
– Missing background checks or lagging account disablement escalates to HR and Security for remediation within five business days.
– Review screening vendors, checklist effectiveness, and timing metrics annually.

name: Information Sharing & Transfer
description: Restricts data transfers to approved encrypted channels, enforces NDAs and minimisation, records international safeguards, and audits transfer logs.

content.text: – Ensure data moves securely between systems, parties, and jurisdictions, preserving confidentiality and integrity.
– All electronic and physical transfers of organisational or customer information.
Use TLS-protected channels (HTTPS, SFTP, VPN) or end-to-end encrypted messaging.
Encrypt physical media; use tracked courier services.
Execute NDA or contract before sharing Confidential or Restricted data.
Share via least-privilege, time-bound links; disable after purpose met.
Share only necessary data fields; mask or anonymise where feasible.
Remove test or debug data from production extracts.
For personal data leaving its origin region, apply recognised safeguards (e.g., Standard Contractual Clauses).
Maintain record of transfer bases in privacy processing log.
Log outbound transfers of Restricted data: date, sender, recipient, content summary, method.
Retain logs for at least one year.
– Quarterly sample of transfer logs shows 100 % encrypted channels and valid agreements.
– One-off unencrypted transfer allowed only for low-sensitivity data with management approval.
– Unauthorised or insecure transfers raise incident response; notify affected parties if required.
– Add automated redaction and secure-send tools; update safeguards with legal changes.

name: Policy Management & Exception Handling
description: Inventories every policy, enforces version control and annual reviews, and documents, time-boxes, and sunsets any approved exceptions.

content.text: – Ensure all governance, security, and privacy policies are current, traceable, and that any deviations are formally approved, time-boxed, and documented.
– All organisational policies and standards, all personnel, and all systems governed by those documents.
Maintain a master list of active policies, each with a named owner.
Store the inventory in a shared repository accessible to all personnel.
Keep policies under version control with commit history.
Include a version number and last-review date in each document.
Notify personnel of major updates within five business days.
Owners review their policies at least once every 12 months.
Document “Reviewed – no change” or note revisions in the change log.
Any employee may request an exception by submitting: scope, justification, risk, compensating controls, proposed expiry.
The policy owner and senior management jointly approve or reject within ten business days.
Record all approved exceptions in an Exception Register with owner and expiry date.
Review the register monthly; close or renew any item reaching expiry.
– Inventory exists; ≥ 90 % of policies show review within 12 months; no exceptions past expiry.
– Handled per 2.6 and logged in the Exception Register.
– Missing reviews or unmanaged exceptions escalated to senior management and corrected within 30 days.
– Incorporate audit findings and user feedback at the next scheduled review.

name: Change & Release Management
description: Requires ticketed, peer-reviewed changes, pre-deployment testing, scheduled releases, emergency-change documentation, and post-release reviews.

content.text: – Deploy code, infrastructure, or configuration changes safely and predictably.
– Production systems, customer-facing services, shared libraries, and core infrastructure.
Create a ticket describing scope, risk, rollback plan.
Require peer review or manager approval before merge/deploy.
Run unit/integration tests or staging deployment when feasible.
Assess security impact; add security tests for high-risk changes.
Schedule non-urgent releases during low-traffic windows.
Notify stakeholders at least 24 h in advance for any expected downtime.
Allowed only to restore service or fix critical security flaws.
Document retrospectively within 24 h and include in next review.
Verify success metrics and error budgets.
Capture lessons learned in release notes or retro.
– 100 % production commits have linked approved ticket; failed change rate tracked.
– Unauthorised change triggers rollback and disciplinary review.
– Analyse change-failure trends quarterly; refine pipeline.

name: Vulnerability & Patch Management
description: Runs routine scans, prioritises patches by CVSS and exploit activity, enforces remediation SLAs, and verifies closure.

content.text: – Detect and remediate software and configuration weaknesses before exploitation.
– Operating systems, applications, containers, dependencies, and network devices.
External attack surface scan monthly; internal scan quarterly or after big changes.
Continuous dependency scanning in CI pipeline.
Critical CVSS ≥ 9 or active exploit: patch within 7 days.
High (7–8.9): 30 days. Medium: 90 days. Low: next maintenance window.
Track each finding in ticketing system with owner and target date.
Document compensating controls if patch not feasible.
Re-scan after patching; ensure finding closed.
Keep 12 months of vulnerability and patch records for auditors.
– ≥ 95 % of critical/high patches applied within SLA.
– Business or technical constraints documented; reviewed quarterly.
– Overdue criticals escalate to leadership; possible production access freeze.
– Adjust SLAs based on threat trends and patch performance.

name: Security & Privacy Awareness Training
description: Delivers onboarding and annual refresher training, role-based modules, simulated phishing, and tracks completion metrics.

content.text: – Equip personnel with knowledge to recognise and respond to security and privacy risks.
– All employees, contractors, interns, and third-party staff with system access.
Core topics: data-classification, phishing, password/MFA, incident reporting, privacy basics.
Complete baseline training within first week of access.
Sign electronic acknowledgement; system access suspended until completed.
Provide refresher micro-modules or lunch-and-learns at least annually.
Deliver specialised modules for engineers (secure coding), support (PII handling), etc.
Users who fall for a phish complete remedial training within five business days.
Track completion in HR or LMS system; retain logs three years.
Report completion rate and phishing-failure rate to management quarterly.
– ≥ 95 % training completion before due date; phishing failure rate trending downward.
– Short-term deferral allowed for leave of absence; complete training within two weeks of return.
– Access restrictions or HR action for repeated failures or missed deadlines.
– Revise curriculum based on incident trends, employee feedback, and threat landscape.

name: P-SD Secure Development Policy
description: This policy embeds secure-coding and data-validation practices into the software development life cycle (SDLC) to preserve processing integrity and prevent unauthorized or malformed data from compromising organizational systems.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who design, develop, test, or maintain software applications and services—whether on-premises or in the cloud—that store, process, or transmit organizational or customer data.
(T-150) Validate software-application input values against defined acceptable ranges to meet processing-integrity objectives.
(T-151) Enforce completion of mandatory fields before accepting any record entry or edit.
(T-152) Limit input values to acceptable ranges to satisfy system-input control requirements.

Developers must submit SDLC-related exception requests through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Application Security Lead and Information Security Officer jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Code reviews, automated scans, and security audits detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate code rollback or legal action.

name: P-EC Encryption & Cryptographic Control Policy
description: This policy establishes requirements for managing encryption, keys, and cryptographic protections to safeguard the confidentiality and integrity of customer and organizational data at rest and in transit.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who design, implement, or manage cryptographic solutions, keys, databases, and network services—whether in production or non-production environments—that store or transmit organizational or customer data.
(T-086) Document and maintain a policy that governs encryption and cryptographic-protection controls, including key generation, storage, rotation, and retirement.
(T-071) Encrypt all production databases that store customer data at rest using approved cryptographic mechanisms.
(T-072) Use industry-standard encryption (e.g., HTTPS with TLS) to keep data confidential during transmission over public or untrusted networks.
(T-073) Apply the same level of cryptographic protection to customer data in non-production environments as in production.
(T-141) Encrypt production databases containing customer data to meet confidentiality objectives.
(T-153) Encrypt production databases to protect system inputs, in-process items, and outputs as specified by system requirements.

Employees must submit cryptographic-control exception requests through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and Data Owner jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated encryption checks, audits, and security reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate key revocation, access removal, or legal action.

name: P-IR Incident Response Policy
description: This policy ensures the organization can rapidly detect, report, and respond to information-security incidents to minimize business impact, fulfill legal obligations, and protect stakeholder interests.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who use, administer, or support organizational information systems, data, or services—across on-premises and cloud environments.
(T-028) Provide employees with clear instructions in the Information Security Policies on how to report failures, incidents, concerns, or complaints.
(T-045) Establish reporting mechanisms that allow employees to communicate internal-control deficiencies promptly and confidentially.
(T-091) Maintain a documented incident-response policy and procedure that defines roles, responsibilities, and guidelines for handling information-security incidents.
(T-089) Document guidelines for notifying customers and other stakeholders in the event of a breach.
(T-090) Maintain records of information-security incidents, including investigations and response-plan execution detail.

Employees must submit incident-response exceptions through the ticketing system, providing justification, compensating controls, and required duration. The Information Security Officer and Incident Response Lead must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Continuous monitoring, audits, and post-incident reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include access revocation or legal action.

name: P-CP Capacity & Performance Management
description: This policy ensures critical assets are continuously monitored for capacity, performance, and anomalous behavior so the organization can anticipate demand, prevent service degradation, and defend against denial-of-service or other capacity-related threats.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who design, operate, or support the organization’s production infrastructure, applications, networks, and cloud resources that handle business-critical workloads.
(T-092) Continuously monitor critical assets and generate capacity alerts that support vulnerability detection.
(T-093) Continuously monitor critical assets for anomaly detection.
(T-094) Continuously monitor critical assets and analyze data for security-event evaluation.
(T-131) Continuously monitor critical assets and generate capacity alerts to ensure optimal performance, meet future capacity requirements, and protect against denial-of-service attacks.

Employees must submit capacity-management exceptions through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Infrastructure Lead and Information Security Officer jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated monitoring, performance audits, and management reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: P-TP Third-Party Risk Management Policy
description: This policy ensures that vendors and other third parties do not introduce unacceptable risk to the organization by establishing a structured program for assessing, monitoring, and mitigating supplier risks aligned with security commitments and regulatory requirements.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and business units that select, onboard, manage, or rely on vendors, subservice organizations, or other third parties that store, process, or transmit organizational data or provide critical services.
(T-032) Perform a formal vendor-risk-assessment exercise at least annually to identify and evaluate vendors critical to system security commitments and requirements.
(T-046) Review and evaluate all subservice organizations periodically to ensure they continue to meet customer commitments.
(T-054) Develop and update general control activities based on insights gained from periodic subservice-organization evaluations.
(T-120) Document policies and procedures for managing vendors and third-party suppliers, including guidance for risk assessment.
(T-121) Document policies and procedures to identify and mitigate vendor risks, incorporating service commitments and system requirements.

Employees must submit third-party-risk exceptions via the ticketing system, outlining business justification, compensating controls, and desired duration. The Information Security Officer and Vendor Owner must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed upon expiration or earlier if risk conditions change.

Vendor audits, continuous monitoring, and management reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are handled under HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—depending on severity, and may include contract suspension or legal action.

name: P-LG Logging Policy
description: This policy mandates continuous monitoring and logging to detect, evaluate, and respond to security events, thereby protecting the integrity, availability, and reliability of organizational systems and controls.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who design, administer, or use the organization’s information systems, networks, and cloud services that generate, store, or analyze security-related logs.
(T-027) Configure systems to generate log information that is reviewed to assess impacts on internal control performance.
(T-043) Use a continuous-monitoring system to track and report the overall health of the information security program.
(T-044) Use a continuous-monitoring system to communicate internal-control deficiencies to stakeholders.
(T-053) Develop and refine control activities through insights gained from the continuous-monitoring system.
(T-087) Use a continuous-monitoring system to evaluate security events and identify failures to meet security objectives.
(T-088) Use a continuous-monitoring system to track and report security incidents to stakeholders.
(T-105) Configure infrastructure to generate audit events for security-related actions to support detection monitoring.
(T-106) Configure infrastructure to review and analyze audit events to detect anomalous activity.
(T-107) Configure infrastructure to generate audit events for system-component monitoring.
(T-108) Configure infrastructure to review and analyze audit events for anomaly detection.
(T-109) Configure infrastructure to generate audit events for security-event evaluation.
(T-110) Configure infrastructure to review and analyze audit events to support incident analysis.

Employees must submit logging exceptions through the ticketing system, detailing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and system owner jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated log reviews, audits, and security monitoring detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include access revocation or legal action.

name: P-IP Information Protection Policy
description: This policy preserves the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of organizational information by establishing clear requirements for data retention and secure disposal, network protections, and strong cryptographic safeguards for data at rest and in transit.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who create, store, transmit, or manage organizational or customer information; and to anyone who administers production or non-production databases, hosts, or network infrastructure in any environment.
Document and maintain guidelines that define retention periods and secure disposal methods for all information assets.
Document a policy for decommissioning information assets containing classified information, including secure sanitization procedures.
(T-128) Document a policy for disposing of confidential information in accordance with confidentiality objectives.
(T-129) Document a policy for decommissioning information assets containing confidential information to meet confidentiality objectives.
(T-074) Prevent public-internet access to production databases and Secure Shell interfaces by enforcing network segmentation and restricted access controls.
(T-075) Protect every production host with a firewall configured with a deny-by-default rule set.
(T-076) Document and implement guidelines for communications protection and network security of critical systems.
(T-071) Encrypt all production databases that store customer data at rest using approved cryptographic mechanisms.
(T-072) Use industry-standard encryption (e.g., HTTPS with TLS) for all data transmitted over public or untrusted networks.
(T-073) Apply the same level of cryptographic protection to customer data in non-production environments as in production.
(T-141) Encrypt production databases containing customer data to meet confidentiality objectives.
(T-153) Encrypt production databases to protect system inputs, in-process items, and outputs as specified.

Employees must submit information-protection exception requests through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and desired duration. The Information Security Officer and data owner jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Continuous monitoring, audits, and incident reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: Privacy & Data-Subject Rights
description: Ensures personal data is processed on a lawful basis, keeps users informed, and fulfils data-subject requests within required timelines.

content.text: – Ensure personal data is processed lawfully, transparently, and that individuals can exercise their privacy rights.
– All personal data relating to customers, end-users, employees, contractors, or any identifiable individuals.
Identify and record a lawful basis (e.g., contract, consent, legitimate interest) for each processing activity.
Collect only data necessary for the stated purpose; review forms and APIs annually to remove unused fields.
Maintain an up-to-date public Privacy Notice describing categories of data, purposes, sharing, retention, and rights.
Update the notice within 30 days of any significant change in processing.
Provide a visible channel (e.g., privacy@ email or web form) for access, correction, deletion, or portability requests.
Verify requester identity and respond within applicable legal timelines.
Log each request, decision, and completion date in a DSR log.
Obtain explicit consent where required; store timestamp and method.
Offer easy withdrawal via self-service or support request.
Sync marketing or product systems to reflect updated preferences within five business days.
Maintain a processing-activity record covering data categories, purposes, bases, recipients, transfers, and safeguards.
Retain DSR logs and consent records for at least three years.
– Quarterly review confirms: processing record current, Privacy Notice updated, DSRs closed on time.
– Any deviation (e.g., extended DSR deadline) documented with justification and regulatory allowance.
– Missed deadlines or undocumented processing triggers incident response and notification to leadership; corrective action required.
– Integrate feedback from users, audits, and regulatory updates into processes and the Privacy Notice.

name: Secure Software Development Lifecycle
description: Embeds security user stories, automated code scans, dependency checks, secrets detection, and pre-release penetration testing into every build.

content.text: – Embed security checks into every stage of software design, development, and deployment.
– All custom code, Infrastructure-as-Code, scripts, and APIs maintained by the organisation.
Capture security user stories or tasks during backlog grooming.
Reference relevant standards (e.g., input validation, auth flows).
Require peer code review for every pull request. OR
Run automated static-analysis tooling with blocking rules on critical findings.
Scan third-party packages for known CVEs on every build.
Isolate build runners; authenticate to artifact repo via short-lived tokens.
Sign release artifacts; verify hash during deployment.
Conduct internal or third-party pen test for major releases or annually.
Track findings to closure before public launch.
– CI pipeline gates show 100 % code scanned; no critical findings open on release.
– Temporary allow-lists require documented risk and fix timeline.
– Code merged without review or scan reverted; build blocked until rectified.
– Integrate new security tooling and OWASP guidance each year.

name: Sanctions & Disciplinary
description: Applies a progressive, documented disciplinary framework for security or privacy violations, ensuring fair process and consistent sanctions.

content.text: – Outline fair, consistent consequences for security or privacy violations.
– All workforce members, regardless of role or contract type.
Apply progressive discipline: coaching → written warning → suspension → termination, unless severity dictates immediate action.
Align severity with impact: data breach, harassment, or unlawful acts may bypass lower steps.
HR and Security jointly investigate alleged violations; gather logs, interviews, and evidence.
Offer the accused an opportunity to provide explanation before decision.
Moderate: written warning plus remedial actions.
Major: suspension, access revocation, potential termination and legal referral.
File investigation report and final action in personnel record.
Provide appeal channel to senior leadership within five business days of sanction notice.
HR maintains sanctions log for trend analysis.
Incorporate policy summary in annual awareness training.
– Quarterly review of sanctions log for consistency and closure of corrective actions.
– Executive leadership may vary sanctions only with documented rationale.
– Failure to follow process prompts HR-led review and policy refresher.
– Adjust framework based on case analytics and legal updates.

name: P-IC Information Classification & Handling Policy
description: This policy ensures all information assets are consistently classified and labeled so they receive protection commensurate with their sensitivity and integrity requirements, reducing the risk of unauthorized disclosure or processing errors.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who create, store, process, transmit, or dispose of organizational information in any form—physical or digital—across all systems, facilities, and cloud environments.
(T-026) Document and maintain policies and procedures for physical and logical labeling of information in accordance with the data-classification scheme.
(T-130) Physically and logically label information systems and media to identify confidential information as required by classification guidelines.
(T-143) Label information systems to support processing-integrity objectives and align with approved data definitions.
(T-144) Apply physical and logical labels to information systems to enforce policies over system inputs that affect processing integrity.

Employees must request classification-related exceptions through the ticketing system, providing business justification, proposed compensating controls, and desired duration. The Information Security Officer and data owner jointly review, approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is re-evaluated at or before expiration.

Audits, automated scans, and monitoring detect misclassification or mishandling of information. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR. Confirmed violations are addressed under HR’s disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include mandatory retraining or legal action.

name: P-RM Risk Management Policy
description: This policy establishes a structured risk management process to identify, analyze, and treat threats that could jeopardize the organization’s ability to meet its security commitments and business objectives.

content.text: The policy applies to all business units, employees, contractors, and third parties involved in planning, operating, or supporting the organization’s information systems, services, and infrastructure across all environments.
(T-029) Perform a formal risk-assessment exercise at least annually, following documented guidelines to identify threats that could impair security commitments and requirements.
(T-030) Assess each identified risk and assign a risk score based on likelihood and impact on confidentiality, integrity, and availability, mapping risks to mitigating factors.
(T-031) Include consideration of potential fraud as a factor in the risk matrix when evaluating risks.
(T-119) Document, maintain, and follow policies and procedures that identify risks to business objectives and incorporate service commitments and system requirements into risk mitigation plans.

Employees must request exceptions via the ticketing system, providing justification, proposed compensating controls, and desired duration. The Information Security Officer and Risk Owner jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed upon expiration or earlier if risk levels change.

Audits and continuous monitoring detect non-compliance with this policy. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are addressed per HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—depending on severity, and may include immediate risk mitigation actions or legal referral.

name: Retention & Secure Disposal
description: Sets record-specific retention periods, runs periodic purge reviews, and requires cryptographic or physical destruction of outdated data.

content.text: – Keep data only as long as it is needed and dispose of it so it cannot be recovered by unauthorised parties.
– All electronic and physical records, backups, and media created or held by the organisation.
Maintain a table listing record types, retention period, and owner.
Review the schedule at least annually and when new data types arise.
Owners run an automated or manual review at least quarterly to identify data beyond its retention period.
Records flagged for deletion are queued for disposal within 30 days.
Electronic data: secure-wipe utilities or crypto-erasure (destroy keys).
Physical media: cross-cut shredding or certified destruction vendor.
Document each disposal event with date, data category, and method.
Apply the same retention timelines to backups and archives.
Encrypt backups; verify they age-out or are re-encrypted when keys rotate.
– Quarterly check shows ≤ 5 % records past retention; disposal logs complete.
– Legal hold or contract may override schedule; document reason and review date.
– Over-retained or improperly disposed records escalated to senior management and remediated within 30 days.
– Update schedule and tooling after audits, incidents, or regulatory change.

name: Encryption & Crypto Controls
description: Mandates strong encryption for data in transit and at rest, governs key generation, storage, rotation, and audits for weak configurations.

content.text: – Protect data confidentiality and integrity with strong, well-managed cryptography.
– All systems, applications, databases, backups, and communications handling sensitive or confidential data.
Enforce TLS 1.2+ (or later) for web, API, email relay, and admin channels.
Disable weak ciphers/protocols; use HSTS where supported.
Enable provider-level encryption for cloud storage, volumes, and managed databases.
Full-disk encryption required on laptops and removable drives.
Generate keys via approved crypto libraries or cloud KMS.
Store keys in managed vault/KMS; keys never hard-coded in source control.
Limit vault access to least-privilege service roles.
Rotate platform/DB master keys at least annually or on suspected compromise.
Revoke and destroy retired keys; document rotation events.
– Monthly scan verifies 100 % TLS coverage and encryption-at-rest flags; vault audit shows no orphaned keys.
– Any legacy system lacking encryption must be isolated and tracked with mitigation plan.
– Plain-text storage or transmission of sensitive data triggers immediate incident response.
– Review algorithms annually; upgrade when industry deprecates current standards.

name: Change Management Policy
description: This policy ensures that all changes to the operating environment are planned, approved, tested, and documented so that system integrity, availability, and accuracy are preserved during and after implementation.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who request, approve, develop, test, or deploy changes to the organization’s applications, infrastructure, and configuration items across production, staging, and development environments.
(T-113) Establish and follow approval procedures before implementing any changes to the operating environment.
(T-114) Document policies and procedures that govern change management activities.
(T-115) Implement standardized procedures to control all changes to the operating environment.
(T-147) Conduct application regression testing during change management to validate key processing for integrity.
(T-148) Require formal approval for changes that affect output accuracy and timeliness.
(T-149) Conduct regression testing to verify accurate output delivery after changes are implemented.
(T-116) Establish approval procedures before implementing configuration changes to the operating environment.
(T-117) Document policies and procedures that govern configuration-change activities.
(T-118) Implement standardized procedures to control all configuration changes to the operating environment.

Employees must submit change-related exception requests through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Change Advisory Board (CAB) and the Information Security Officer must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated logging, change audits, and management reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are handled under HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity and may include change rollback or legal action.

name: P-AM Asset Management Policy
description: This policy ensures that all organizational assets are identified, assigned ownership, and protected according to their value and risk, reducing the likelihood of loss, misuse, or inadequate accountability.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who create, use, maintain, or dispose of the organization’s information assets, including hardware, software, data, and cloud resources across all environments.
(T-015) Establish mechanisms to assign and manage asset ownership and to ensure a common understanding of protection requirements.
(T-041) Assign and manage asset ownership responsibilities as part of an ongoing evaluation process.
(T-042) Periodically update and review the system inventory as part of ongoing evaluations.
(T-060) Develop, document, and maintain an inventory of organizational infrastructure systems for accountability.

Employees must submit asset-related exception requests through the ticketing system, including business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and asset owner must approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated monitoring and periodic audits detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR. Confirmed violations are addressed under HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include revocation of access or legal action.

name: P-AC Access Control Policy
description: This policy establishes controls that limit access to information systems and data to authorized users, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or disruption of critical services.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who request, grant, or use logical or physical access to the organization’s production consoles, databases, applications, networks, endpoints, and cloud environments—whether on-site or remote.
(T-055) Review and approve the list of individuals with production-console access at least annually.
(T-062) Require authorized personnel to approve logical access provisioning to critical systems based on individual need or predefined role.
(T-063) Document policies and procedures that register and authorize users before issuing system credentials.
(T-064) Use continuous monitoring to alert the security team to adjust access levels promptly when roles change.
(T-065) Periodically review and confirm that access to critical systems is limited to personnel who require it.
(T-066) Periodically review and confirm that administrative access to critical systems is limited to personnel who require it.
(T-067) Remove or disable logical access promptly when it is no longer required, including upon termination.
(T-068) Restrict production-database access to personnel whose job functions require it.
(T-145) Require documented approval for logical access provisioning to critical systems to ensure accurate and timely output delivery.
(T-146) Document policies and procedures that govern access control for storing inputs, in-process items, and outputs according to system specifications.
(T-069) Document and publish guidelines for password management and secure login mechanisms.
(T-070) Enforce secure login mechanisms, including multi-factor authentication, for all staff with access to critical systems.
(T-079) Perform security and privacy compliance checks on software versions and patches of remote devices before allowing internal connections.
(T-080) Configure endpoints that access critical servers or data to auto-lock after 15 minutes of inactivity.
(T-111) Conduct ongoing security and privacy compliance checks on remote devices to support security-event evaluation.
(T-059) Segregate responsibilities and duties to mitigate risks to customer services.

Employees must submit access-related exception requests through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and system owner jointly review and approve or reject each request. Approved exceptions are documented, time-bound, and reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated monitoring, periodic audits, and managerial oversight detect access-control violations. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are addressed under HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: P-BC Business Continuity Policy
description: This policy ensures the organization can quickly restore critical operations after a disruption by maintaining reliable backups, robust disaster-recovery plans, and validated continuity procedures, thereby reducing the risk of prolonged outages, data loss, and safety hazards.

content.text: The policy applies to all business units, employees, contractors, and third parties who design, operate, or support the organization’s information systems, infrastructure, and facilities—whether on-premises or in the cloud—that are required to sustain or restore business operations.
(T-102) Document a policy that defines data-backup management requirements for security-incident recovery.
(T-132) Document a policy that aligns data-backup practices with established recovery-time and recovery-point objectives.
(T-133) Back up user and system data regularly to meet recovery objectives and verify backup integrity.
(T-134) Test backup media periodically to confirm reliability and information integrity.
(T-138) Test backup data periodically as part of recovery-plan validation.
(T-103) Document guidelines that govern disaster-recovery activities required to sustain business operations.
(T-135) Document guidelines that address disaster recovery for environmental protection and business continuity.
(T-139) Document disaster-recovery guidelines that specify procedures for recovery-plan testing.
(T-104) Document policies and procedures that support ongoing business operations and contingency controls.
(T-136) Document contingency-planning controls that protect operations and the environment.
(T-140) Document business-continuity policies that define requirements for recovery-plan testing.
(T-137) Conduct regular tests and exercises to evaluate the effectiveness and readiness of the contingency plan.

Employees must submit business-continuity exceptions through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and Business Continuity Manager review each request; approved exceptions are documented, time-bound, and re-evaluated at or before expiration.

Audits, monitoring tools, and incident reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are addressed under HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—according to severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: P-IS Information Security Program
description: This policy defines and governs the organization’s information security program to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information assets and to reduce risks arising from inadequate governance, oversight, or staff awareness.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who design, build, manage, or use the organization’s information systems, data, networks, facilities, and cloud services across all locations.
(T-002) Establish procedures requiring staff to periodically acknowledge all applicable company policies.
(T-003) Establish procedures requiring new staff to acknowledge applicable company policies during onboarding.
(T-022) Make all policies and procedures readily available for staff review.
(T-127) Document an Information Security Policy that governs the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information systems.
(T-004) Outline and document cybersecurity responsibilities for all personnel.
(T-005) Communicate roles and responsibilities to staff through established procedures.
(T-006) Maintain an organizational structure that defines authorities, facilitates information flow, and establishes responsibilities.
(T-007) Appoint a Compliance Program Manager responsible for planning and implementing the internal control environment.
(T-008) Assign an Information Security Officer to centrally manage and maintain the enterprise-wide cybersecurity and privacy program.
(T-009) Appoint a People Operations Officer to develop and drive personnel-related security strategies.
(T-033) Delegate the Information Security Officer to coordinate, develop, implement, and maintain the enterprise-wide cybersecurity and privacy program.
(T-010) Ensure senior management reviews and approves all company policies at least annually.
(T-011) Ensure senior management reviews and approves the organizational chart for all employees annually.
(T-012) Ensure senior management reviews and approves the Risk Assessment Report annually.
(T-013) Ensure senior management reviews and approves the Information Security Program at planned intervals or upon significant change.
(T-014) Ensure senior management reviews and approves the Vendor Risk Assessment Report annually.
(T-034) Conduct annual policy reviews to evaluate ongoing effectiveness.
(T-035) Conduct annual organizational chart reviews to evaluate ongoing effectiveness.
(T-036) Conduct annual risk assessment reviews to evaluate ongoing effectiveness.
(T-037) Conduct ongoing evaluations of Information Security Program effectiveness.
(T-038) Conduct annual vendor risk assessment reviews to evaluate ongoing effectiveness.
(T-039) Communicate Information Security Program status to senior management for corrective action.
(T-040) Communicate policy compliance status to senior management for corrective action.
(T-048) Develop control activities based on insights from annual policy reviews.
(T-049) Develop control activities based on insights from annual organizational chart reviews.
(T-050) Develop control activities based on insights from annual risk assessment reviews.
(T-051) Develop control activities based on insights from Information Security Program reviews.
(T-052) Develop control activities based on insights from annual vendor risk assessment reviews.
(T-021) Require periodic evaluations of employees in IT, Engineering, and Information Security roles to confirm responsibilities are fulfilled.
(T-024) Display current service information on a customer-accessible website.
(T-025) Provide customers with clear instructions for reporting failures, incidents, concerns, or complaints.
(T-122) Document policies and procedures that establish expected behavior within the control environment.
(T-123) Document policies and procedures that support general control activities over technology.
(T-124) Deploy control activities in accordance with documented policies and procedures.
(T-016) Perform security risk screening of individuals before authorizing access.
(T-017) Ensure security-related positions are staffed by qualified personnel with necessary skills.
(T-018) Provide job-related information security and privacy training to staff.
(T-019) Require new staff to complete security and privacy literacy training during onboarding.
(T-020) Document, monitor, and retain individual training activities and records.

Employees must submit exception requests via the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and Compliance Program Manager must approve, document, and time-bound each exception, which is reviewed at expiration or sooner if conditions change.

Automated monitoring, audits, and management reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are addressed under HR’s disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity and intent, and may include access revocation or legal action.

name: P-EP Endpoint Protection Policy
description: This policy safeguards the organization’s information assets by ensuring endpoints are protected against malware, encrypted against unauthorized access, and accurately inventoried, thereby minimizing the risk of compromise, data loss, or service disruption.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who configure, use, or manage organizational endpoints—laptops, desktops, mobile devices, and servers—whether on-premises or remote, that access, store, or process organizational data.
(T-078) Ensure endpoints that access critical servers or data are protected by approved malware-protection software.
(T-084) Document and maintain policies and procedures that govern endpoint security and related controls.
(T-085) Develop, document, and maintain an inventory of organizational endpoint systems, capturing details necessary for accountability.
(T-082) Encrypt endpoints that access critical servers or data to prevent unauthorized access.
(T-083) Encrypt all critical endpoints to prevent unauthorized access.
(T-142) Encrypt endpoints that access critical servers or data to protect confidential information from unauthorized disclosure.

Employees must request endpoint-security exceptions through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and system owner jointly review, approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is re-evaluated at or before expiration.

Automated monitoring, audits, and security reviews detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity and may include immediate access revocation, device quarantine, or legal action.

name: P-AU Acceptable Use Policy
description: Define acceptable behaviour and technology usage so employees safeguard organisational assets, uphold confidentiality, integrity and availability, and foster a respectful work environment.

content.text: This policy applies to all employees, contractors, interns and third parties who access or use the organisation’s information systems, networks, devices or data in any location (office, remote or hybrid) from onboarding through off-boarding.
Access company resources only with unique, organisation-issued credentials protected by multi-factor authentication; never share secrets or leave sessions unattended.
Maintain device hygiene: install security patches promptly, run approved endpoint protection, enable full-disk encryption and auto-lock screens after ≤ 5 minutes idle.
Store sensitive data only in approved services; transmit it via encrypted channels (e.g., VPN, TLS); copying to personal storage requires written approval.
Use a corporate VPN on untrusted networks and refrain from operating rogue Wi-Fi, personal hotspots or network-scanning tools without authorisation.
Prohibited activities include pirated software, illegal content, harassment, crypto-mining, personal commercial ventures and any action that degrades service or security.
All activity on corporate assets may be logged and reviewed to defend against threats; users have no expectation of personal privacy on these assets.
Personal devices (BYOD) accessing company data must enrol in mobile-device management and may be remotely wiped on termination or suspected compromise.
New personnel acknowledge all applicable policies during onboarding.
All personnel re-acknowledge annually (or when significant changes occur) to reinforce accountability and awareness.

Employees request acceptable-use exceptions through the ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls and duration. The Information Security Officer and HR jointly approve, document and time-limit each exception, reviewing it at or before expiration.

Automated monitoring, audits and management oversight detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: P-SA Security Awareness & Training Policy
description: This policy promotes a security-conscious culture by setting behavioral expectations and ensuring all personnel possess the knowledge and qualifications necessary to safeguard organizational assets.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who access, manage, or support the organization’s information systems, devices, and data—whether on-site or remote.
(T-001) Document a policy that defines behavioral standards and acceptable business conduct.
(T-047) Establish guidelines for acceptable and unacceptable technology usage, including consequences for violations.
(T-125) Require staff to periodically acknowledge applicable company policies to reinforce confidentiality objectives.
(T-126) Require new staff to acknowledge applicable company policies during onboarding to support confidentiality objectives.
(T-016) Perform security risk screening of individuals before authorizing access.
(T-017) Ensure security-related positions are staffed by qualified individuals with the necessary skill sets.
(T-018) Provide information security and privacy training tailored to each staff member’s job functions.
(T-019) Require new staff to complete security and privacy literacy training during onboarding.
(T-020) Document, monitor, and retain individual training activities and records.

Employees must submit written exception requests through the ticketing system, including business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and HR must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Monitoring, audits, and management oversight detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include mandatory retraining or legal action.

name: Access Control & Least Privilege
description: Implements a Joiner-Mover-Leaver workflow, role-based access control, quarterly reviews, and strict approval for elevated privileges.

content.text: – Ensure users receive only the minimum access necessary and that access adjusts promptly with role changes.
– All workforce accounts, service accounts, and system roles across SaaS, IaaS, and on-prem resources.
Provision access via ticket with manager approval.
Modify privileges within 48 h of role change.
Disable or delete accounts by end of final workday.
Define standard roles per system (e.g., Admin, User, Read-Only).
Assign users to roles; avoid direct entitlements wherever possible.
Temporary admin rights require documented business justification and auto-expire ≤ 24 h.
All permanent admin assignments approved by senior management.
System owners review user lists at least quarterly; remove stale or excessive rights.
Document review date, reviewers, and actions.
– Quarterly review shows ≤ 2 % orphaned accounts; all admin rights have approval record.
– Emergency access allowed max 8 h; log reason and close in next review.
– Unapproved elevated access or dormant accounts >30 days escalated to management and remediated within one week.
– Incorporate review findings to refine role definitions and automate provisioning.

name: Logging, Monitoring & Audit
description: Centralises and protects logs, sets real-time alerting for critical events, retains audit trails, and reviews metrics and samples monthly.

content.text: – Provide trustworthy evidence for security, troubleshooting, and compliance by collecting and analysing relevant logs.
– Application, system, network, authentication, and cloud-provider logs across all environments.
Forward logs to a central, access-controlled SIEM or log service.
Include timestamp, user, event type, source IP for security-relevant events.
Retain security logs at least 90 days online and 1 year archive.
Restrict write access to logging system; prohibit log tampering or deletion.
Create alerts for key events: failed admin logins, privilege escalations, critical errors.
Send alerts to on-call channel; maintain documented runbooks.
Review alert metrics and random log samples monthly.
Produce quarterly audit report summarising anomalies and actions.
Sync all servers and devices to trusted NTP source; alert on drift >5 s.
– Central platform receives ≥ 95 % of target logs; alert queue triaged within SLA.
– Systems unable to forward logs must export daily and upload; document in asset list.
– Logging gaps >24 h or unreviewed alerts escalated to incident response.
– Add new log sources and refine alert logic based on incident learnings.

name: Backup, Business Continuity & Disaster Recovery
description: Establishes backup frequency, off-site encrypted storage, quarterly restore tests, and concise BCP/DR activation playbooks.

content.text: – Ensure critical data and services can be restored within acceptable time and data-loss targets after disruption.
– Production databases, file stores, configuration repositories, and essential SaaS services.
Perform full backups daily for critical production data; retain at least 30 days online.
Snapshot infrastructure-as-code and configs before each major change.
Store backups in geographically separate region or provider.
Encrypt at rest using managed keys; restrict restore permissions to limited roles.
Test restores quarterly; record actual Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO).
Compare results to targets and adjust strategy if exceeded.
Keep concise BCP playbook covering loss of workspace, key staff, or SaaS outage.
Review BCP annually or after significant operational change.
Define DR trigger thresholds; Incident Commander authorises activation.
Maintain contact list for critical vendors and service providers.
– ≥ 95 % backup success rate; latest quarterly restore test documented and within target RTO/RPO.
– Systems excluded from backup require documented justification and alternative mitigation.
– Missed backups or failed restore tests escalate to leadership for immediate remediation.
– Incorporate findings from DR exercises and technology advances into backup/BCP strategy.

name: P-VM Vulnerability Management Policy
description: This policy ensures timely identification, evaluation, and remediation of vulnerabilities to prevent exploitation, reduce business impact, and maintain the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of organizational systems and data.

content.text: The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third-party service providers who design, administer, or use organizational platforms, infrastructure, applications, and endpoints—whether on-premises or remote.
(T-095) Identify vulnerabilities on the company platform by performing regular vulnerability scans for detection monitoring.
(T-098) Identify vulnerabilities through periodic scans that monitor individual system components.
(T-101) Identify vulnerabilities annually through penetration testing to prevent security incidents.
(T-096) Track and remediate all identified vulnerabilities in accordance with documented procedures.
(T-099) Track vulnerabilities and remediate them to support anomaly analysis.
(T-097) Document policies and procedures that establish guidelines for managing technical vulnerabilities.
(T-100) Document vulnerability-management guidelines that support security-event evaluation.
(T-081) Perform security and privacy compliance checks on software versions and patches of remote devices before internal connections are established.
(T-112) Perform ongoing security and privacy compliance checks on devices to support security-event evaluation and incident prevention.

Employees must submit vulnerability-management exception requests through the ticketing system, detailing business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Information Security Officer and Vulnerability Management Lead must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Automated scans, patch-status reports, and security audits detect non-compliance. Suspected violations are reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may include immediate access revocation or legal action.

name: P-PS Physical Security Policy
description: Appoint Compliance Program Manager delegated with responsibility for planning and implementing internal control environment

content.text: This policy establishes controls that ensure the physical security of the organization’s assets, facilities, and personnel. The goal is to prevent unauthorized physical access, damage, or interference to the organization’s premises and critical infrastructure.

This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who enter or request access to the organization’s premises, including but not limited to offices, data centers, secure rooms, and other physical locations housing critical infrastructure.
Maintain an up-to-date list of individuals authorized for physical access to secure areas, and review this list at least annually.
Require approval from authorized personnel (e.g., manager, security officer) for physical access provisioning to secure areas based on individual need or predefined role.
Document procedures to register and authorize visitors and temporary staff before granting them physical access.
Implement continuous monitoring (e.g., CCTV, security personnel) to detect and respond to unauthorized physical access attempts.
Periodically review and confirm that access to secure areas is restricted to personnel who require it for their job functions.
Immediately revoke or disable physical access when it is no longer required, including upon termination or change of role.
Restrict physical access to critical infrastructure (e.g., server rooms, data centers) to authorized personnel only.
Require documented approval for any physical access to critical infrastructure, ensuring proper authorization and audit trails.
Implement controls for issuing, tracking, and managing physical keys, access cards, or badges.
Require secure storage of spare keys or master keys in a locked cabinet accessible only to authorized personnel.
Periodically review issued keys and badges to ensure they are returned or deactivated when no longer required.
Deploy and maintain surveillance systems (e.g., CCTV) in critical areas, ensuring continuous recording and appropriate retention.
Monitor physical security systems and alarms to ensure timely detection of security events.
Conduct regular inspections of physical security measures (e.g., locks, doors, barriers) to ensure they are functional and effective.
Segregate duties among security personnel, facilities management, and IT staff to mitigate risks related to physical security breaches.

Employees must submit physical security exception requests through the designated ticketing system, providing business justification, compensating controls, and the requested duration. The Information Security Officer and Facilities Manager jointly review, approve, or reject each request. Approved exceptions are documented, time-bound, and reviewed prior to expiration.

Physical security violations are detected through surveillance, periodic audits, and managerial oversight. Suspected violations must be reported to the Information Security Officer and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations are addressed according to HR disciplinary policies—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—depending on severity, and may include immediate revocation of access or legal action.

name: P-PR Privacy Policy
description: This policy embeds privacy-by-design principles across all business processes to protect personal data, meet global regulatory requirements, and maintain stakeholder trust.

content.text: The policy applies to every employee, contractor, and third party that collects, uses, stores, shares, or disposes of personal data on behalf of the organization in any location or system.
(T-154) Integrate privacy principles into product and process design through documented policies and procedures.
(T-155) Publish and maintain a Privacy Policy that satisfies applicable regulatory requirements on the company website.
(T-156) Include Privacy Act statements on all forms that collect information for systems of records.
(T-160) Document a Data Protection Policy assigning staff responsibilities for handling personal data.
(T-167) Appoint a Privacy Officer to oversee and facilitate regulatory compliance.
(T-157) Maintain an up-to-date inventory of personal-data categories with sources, usage, and purposes recorded.
(T-158) Obtain user consent as required before processing personal data.
(T-175) Document procedures for providing privacy notices to data subjects.
(T-176) Update and communicate changes to privacy practices to data subjects in a timely manner.
(T-177) Communicate choices available for collection, use, retention, disclosure, and disposal of personal data.
(T-178) Obtain explicit consent for processing personal data when required.
(T-179) Document the basis for determining implicit consent where permitted.
(T-181) Explain the need for explicit consent and the consequences of failure to provide it.
(T-192) Obtain consent before disclosing personal data to third parties for privacy objectives.
(T-162) Document retention and disposal guidelines for personal data.
(T-180) Collect personal data only for stated privacy objectives.
(T-182) Limit personal-data use to identified privacy objectives.
(T-183) Retain personal data in line with privacy objectives and legal requirements.
(T-184) Securely dispose of personal data when no longer required.
(T-201) Maintain complete and accurate personal-data records throughout the lifecycle.
(T-163) Honour Subject-Access Requests in accordance with this policy.
