(T-185) Grant data subjects access to stored personal data for review.
(T-186) Provide copies of personal data upon request in electronic or physical form.
(T-187) Inform data subjects of access denial and the reasons when applicable.
(T-188) Correct, amend, or append personal data on valid data-subject request.
(T-189) Communicate corrections to third parties as committed or required.
(T-190) Inform data subjects of correction denial and the reasons when applicable.
(T-200) Provide an accounting of personal data held and disclosures on request.
(T-165) Conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments to evaluate regulatory risks.
(T-166) Perform vendor privacy-risk assessments for third parties handling personal data.
(T-168) Assess suspected data breaches and notify affected parties without undue delay.
(T-159) Maintain a list of contractual privacy obligations derived from customer contracts.
(T-164) Ensure appropriate remediation when personal data is shared with vendors.
(T-173) Document a vendor-management policy that incorporates privacy-risk assessment guidance.
(T-195) Obtain written privacy commitments from vendors and third parties with personal-data access.
(T-196) Assess vendor privacy compliance periodically and initiate corrective action when needed.
(T-197) Require vendors to notify the organization of unauthorized personal-data disclosures.
(T-198) Report vendor notifications to the appropriate personnel per incident-response procedures.
(T-172) Apply documented procedures to ensure cross-border personal-data transfers comply with applicable laws.
(T-161) Require authorized approval for logical-access provisioning to privacy-related systems.
(T-174) Provide employees with instructions for reporting privacy failures, incidents, and complaints.
(T-169) Document guidelines for notifying customers and stakeholders of privacy breaches.

(T-191) Disclose personal data to third parties only with explicit data-subject consent.

(T-194) Create and retain accurate, timely records of unauthorized personal-data disclosures.
(T-202) Implement a process for receiving, addressing, and resolving privacy inquiries, complaints, and disputes.
(T-203) Monitor privacy-program compliance and take corrective actions for identified deficiencies.
(T-204) Communicate resolutions of privacy inquiries, complaints, and disputes to data subjects.

Employees must submit privacy-related exception requests through the ticketing system, including business justification, compensating controls, and requested duration. The Privacy Officer and Information Security Officer must jointly approve, document, and time-limit each exception, which is reviewed at or before expiration.

Audits, monitoring tools, and incident reviews detect non-compliance with this policy. Suspected violations are reported to the Privacy Officer, Information Security Officer, and HR for investigation. Confirmed violations follow HR disciplinary tiers—verbal warning, written warning, suspension, or termination—based on severity, and may involve regulatory notification or legal action.

name: Authentication & Password
description: Defines robust password rules, enforces MFA on sensitive systems, secures credential storage, and locks or resets risky accounts.

content.text: – Provide strong, user-friendly authentication that resists brute-force and credential-stuffing attacks.
– All human and service accounts accessing organisational applications, devices, and infrastructure.
Minimum 12 characters or passphrase; prohibit commonly breached strings.
No forced periodic rotation unless compromise suspected.
Unique password per system; store passwords in an approved password manager.
Enforce MFA for admin accounts, remote access, and any system holding Confidential or Restricted data.
Prefer authenticator apps or hardware tokens; SMS only as fallback.
Hash user passwords with bcrypt/Argon2 (min 10 rounds) and per-user salt.
Transmit login data only over TLS.
Never embed secrets in code repositories.
Lock accounts after 5 failed attempts within 15 minutes; auto-unlock after 30 minutes or admin reset.
Identity-verify users before password reset; issue time-limited reset links.
– Automated scans ensure MFA enabled on 100 % target systems; random password audit shows compliance with length policy.
– Systems lacking MFA require documented risk acceptance and compensating controls (e.g., IP-allowlist).
– Weak or reused passwords, or disabled MFA, trigger immediate password reset and user retraining.
– Review emerging passwordless options; adopt stronger methods when widely supported.

name: Incident Response & Breach Notification
description: Defines detection, triage, containment, communication, legal notification, and post-incident lessons with clear team roles.

content.text: – Ensure security and privacy incidents are identified, contained, reported, and resolved quickly, and that required notifications are issued on time.
– All information assets, personnel, third-party services, and physical locations.
Security tools forward real-time alerts to an incident channel.
Anyone discovering suspicious activity must report to security within one hour.
Log every alert or report in the incident tracker with date/time.
Assign Incident Commander, Technical Lead, Communications Lead, and Scribe; publish roster with 24 × 7 contacts.
Maintain runbooks for malware, data breach, DDoS, and cloud compromise scenarios.
Isolate affected systems within 30 minutes of confirmation.
Capture forensics where feasible; patch, clean, or rebuild before re-connect.
Document actions and timestamps in tracker.
Notify management immediately for incidents involving personal or regulated data.
Draft customer/regulator notices within legal time-frames (e.g., 72 h for personal-data breaches).
Route all external statements through Communications Lead and legal counsel.
Conduct root-cause post-mortem within 10 business days.
Record corrective actions, owners, and due dates; track to closure.
– Track mean time to detect (MTTD), mean time to contain (MTTC), and breach-notification deadlines; review quarterly.
– Process deviations allowed only if required to protect life, safety, or critical systems; document afterward.
– Unreported or mishandled incidents escalate to executive review; may trigger disciplinary action.
– Update runbooks and tooling after each post-mortem or external audit finding.
